00018                            data.registers.integer_registers)
00019 /*!< Macro used in the system call switch to access the arguments to the
00020      system call. */

00022 #define KERNEL_VERSION          (0x0000000100000000)
00023 /*!< Kernel version number. */

00025 #define MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROCESSES (16)
00026 /*!< Size of the process_table. */

00032 /*! Defines an execution context. */
00033 struct context
00034 {
00035  char     fpu_context[512];
00036  /*!< Stores the fpu/mmx/sse registers */
00037  struct
00038  {
00039   long    rax;
00040   long    rbx;
00041   long    rcx;
00042   long    rdx;
00043   long    rdi;
00044   long    rsi;
00045   long    rbp;
00046   long    rsp;
00047   long    r8;
00048   long    r9;
00049   long    r10;
00050   long    r11;
00051   long    r12;
00052   long    r13;
00053   long    r14;
00054   long    r15;
00055   long    rflags;   /*!< status flags */
00056   long    rip;      /*!< instruction pointer */
00057  }        integer_registers;
00058  /*!< Stores all user visible integer registers. The segment registers are not
00059       stored as the user mode processes can only use a code and a data segment
00060       descriptor. We assume that the cs is set to the code and all the rest
00061       of the segment registers are set to the data segment all the time. */
00062  char     from_interrupt;
00063  /*!< Is set to 1 if the context is saved during the processing of interrupts.
00064       Set to 0 otherwise. */
00065 };
00066 
00067 /*! Defines a thread. */
00068 union thread
00069 {
00070  struct
00071  {
00072   struct context registers;     /*!< The context of the thread. Note: the
00073                                      context of the thread could include more
00074                                      than the accessible registers. */
00075   int            owner;         /*!< An index, into the process table, that
00076                                      identifies the process that owns this
00077                                      thread. */
00078   int            next;          /*!< This is an index into the thread_table.
00079                                      The index corresponds to the thread
00080                                      following this thread in a linked list.
00081                                      A thread can be in a number of linked
00082                                      lists. */
00083   unsigned long  list_data;     /*!< This member variable has different
00084                                      meaning depending on what list the thread
00085                                      resides in. In the timer queue this
00086                                      variable is either an absolute time or a
00087                                      delta time.*/
00088  }               data;
00089  char            padding[1024];
00090 };
00091 
00092 /*! Defines a process. */
00093 struct process
00094 {
00095  int             threads;       /*!< The number of threads running in this
00096                                      process. */
00097  int             parent;        /*!< This is an index into process_table. The
00098                                      index corresponds to the parent process.
00099                                  */
00100  unsigned long   page_table_root; /*!< Address of the page table tree. */
00101 };
00102 
00103 /* ELF image structures. The names from the ELF64 specification are used and
00104    the structs are derived from the ELF64 specification. */
00105 
00106 #define EI_MAG0       0  /*!< The first four bytes in an ELF image is
00107                               0x7f 'E' 'L' 'F'. */
00108 #define EI_MAG1       1
00109 #define EI_MAG2       2
00110 #define EI_MAG3       3
00111 #define EI_CLASS      4  /*!< The specific ELF image class. */
00112 #define EI_DATA       5  /*!< Describes if the image is big- or little-
00113                               endian. */
00114 #define EI_VERSION    6  /*!< The version of the ELF specification the
00115                               image adheres to. */
00116 #define EI_OSABI      7  /*!< Type of OS the image can be run on. */
00117 #define EI_ABIVERSION 8  /*!< Version of the ABI used. */
00118 #define EI_PAD        9  /*!< First unused byte in the identification array.
00119                           */
00120 #define EI_NIDENT     16 /*!< Number of entries in the identification array */
00121 
00122 /*! Defines an ELF64 file header. */
00123 struct Elf64_Ehdr
00124 {
00125  unsigned char e_ident[EI_NIDENT]; /*!< Array of bytes that shows that this
00126                                         is an ELF image and what type of ELF
00127                                         image it is. */
00128  short         e_type;             /*!< The type of ELF executable image. */
00129  short         e_machine;          /*!< Identifies the type of machine that
00130                                         the image can execute on. */
00131  int           e_version;          /*!< The version of the ELF specification the
00132                                         image adheres to. */
00133  long          e_entry;            /*!< Start address of the executable. */
00134  long          e_phoff;            /*!< The offset into the image where the
00135                                         program header table is found. */
00136  long          e_shoff;            /*!< The offset into the image where the
00137                                         program header table is found. */
00138  int           e_flags;            /*!< Flags that are machine specific.
00139                                         These can be used to differentiate
00140                                         between similar machines. */
00141  short         e_ehsize;           /*!< The size, in bytes, of the header. */
00142  short         e_phentsize;        /*!< The size, in bytes, of each entry in
00143                                         the program header table. */
00144  short         e_phnum;            /*!< The size, in entries, of the program
00145                                         header table. */
00146  short         e_shentsize;        /*!< The size, in bytes, of each entry in
00147                                         the section header table. */
00148  short         e_shnum;            /*!< The size, in entries, of the section
00149                                         header table. */
00150  short         e_shstrndx;         /*!< The index, into the section table,
00151                                         of the section name string table.*/
00152 };
00153 
00154 /*! Defines an ELF32 file header. This is used for the kernel image itself. */
00155 struct Elf32_Ehdr
00156 {
00157  unsigned char e_ident[EI_NIDENT]; /*!< Array of bytes that shows that this
00158                                         is an ELF image and what type of ELF
00159                                         image it is. */
00160  short         e_type;             /*!< The type of ELF executable image. */
00161  short         e_machine;          /*!< Identifies the type of machine that
00162                                         the image can execute on. */
00163  int           e_version;          /*!< The version of the ELF specification the
00164                                         image adheres to. */
00165  int           e_entry;            /*!< Start address of the executable. */
00166  int           e_phoff;            /*!< The offset into the image where the
00167                                         program header table is found. */
00168  int           e_shoff;            /*!< The offset into the image where the
00169                                         program header table is found. */
00170  int           e_flags;            /*!< Flags that are machine specific.
00171                                         These can be used to differentiate
00172                                         between similar machines. */
00173  short         e_ehsize;           /*!< The size, in bytes, of the header. */
00174  short         e_phentsize;        /*!< The size, in bytes, of each entry in
00175                                         the program header table. */
00176  short         e_phnum;            /*!< The size, in entries, of the program
00177                                         header table. */
00178  short         e_shentsize;        /*!< The size, in bytes, of each entry in
00179                                         the section header table. */
00180  short         e_shnum;            /*!< The size, in entries, of the section
00181                                         header table. */
00182  short         e_shstrndx;         /*!< The index, into the section table,
00183                                         of the section name string table.*/
00184 };
00185 
00186 /*! Defines an entry in the ELF program header table. Each entry corresponds
00187     to a segment. */
00188 struct Elf64_Phdr
00189 {
00190  int  p_type;   /*!< Segments can have several types. p_type holds the type. */
00191  int  p_flags;  /*!< The attribute flags of the segment. */
00192  long p_offset; /*!< Offset into the image of the first byte of the
00193                      segment */
00194  long p_vaddr;  /*!< The (virtual) address to which the segment is to be
00195                      loaded. */
00196  long p_paddr;  /*!< Not used. */
00197  long p_filesz; /*!< The number of bytes the segment occupies in the
00198                      image. */
00199  long p_memsz;  /*!< The number of bytes the segment occupies in memory. */
00200  long p_align;  /*!< The alignment the segment should have in memory. This
00201                      field is currently being ignored. */
00202 };
00203 
00204 /*! Defines an entry in the ELF32 program header table. Each entry corresponds
00205     to a segment. */
00206 struct Elf32_Phdr
00207 {
00208  int  p_type;   /*!< Segments can have several types. p_type holds the type. */
00209  int  p_offset; /*!< Offset into the image of the first byte of the
00210                      segment */
00211  int  p_vaddr;  /*!< The (virtual) address to which the segment is to be
00212                      loaded. */
00213  int  p_paddr;  /*!< Not used. */
00214  int  p_filesz; /*!< The number of bytes the segment occupies in the
00215                      image. */
00216  int  p_memsz;  /*!< The number of bytes the segment occupies in memory. */
00217  int  p_flags;  /*!< The attribute flags of the segment. */
00218  int  p_align;  /*!< The alignment the segment should have in memory. This
00219                      field is currently being ignored. */
00220 };
00221 
00222 /* Values used in p_type */
00223 #define PT_NULL 0 /*!< The entry is not used. */
00224 #define PT_LOAD 1 /*!< The segment can be loaded into memory. */
00225 #define PT_PHDR 6 /*!< The segment only hold a program header table. */
00226 /* Values used in p_flags */
00227 #define PF_X        0x1        /*!< Segment can be executed.*/
00228 #define PF_W        0x2        /*!< Segment can be written. */
00229 #define PF_R        0x4        /*!< Segment can be read. */
00230 #define PF_MASKPERM 0x0000FFFF /*!< Used to mask the permission bits */
00231 
00232 /* Data structures describing the executable images embedded in the kernel
00233    image. */
00234 
00235 /*! Defines an executable program. */
00236 struct executable
00237 {
00238  const struct Elf64_Ehdr* elf_image;             /*!< The start of the ELF
00239                                                       file header. */
00240  unsigned long            memory_footprint_size; /*!< Size in bytes of the
00241                                                       program's memory foot
00242                                                       print when loaded. */
00243 };
00244 
00245 /*! Defines an executable image embedded into the kernel image. The executable
00246     images are linked together into a linked list. The linked list is built at
00247     link time, see the kernel link script. */
00248 struct executable_image
00249 {
00250  const struct executable_image* const next; /*!< Points to the next
00251                                                  executable image. The last
00252                                                  executable image in the list
00253                                                  will have a next pointer
00254                                                  equal to 0, i.e., null. */
00255  const struct Elf64_Ehdr              elf_image; /*!< The ELF image file 
00256                                                       header. */
00257 };
00258 
00259 /*! Defines the structure pointed to by the kernel GS_BASE. Every CPU has one
00260     of these. */
00261 struct CPU_private
00262 {
00263  unsigned long  scratch_space;   /*!< Temporary storage used during  context
00264                                       switches. */
00265  unsigned long  page_table_root; /*!< The root of the page table in use on
00266                                       the CPU. */
00267  int            thread_index;    /*!< Index into thread_table of the thread
00268                                       executing on the CPU. The idle thread
00269                                       has index -1. */
00270  int            ticks_left_of_time_slice;
00271                                  /*!< Can be used by a preemptive scheduler. */
00272 };

00276 extern union thread
00277 thread_table[MAX_NUMBER_OF_THREADS];
00278 /*!< Array holding all threads in the systems. */
00279 
00280 extern struct process
00281 process_table[MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROCESSES];
00282 /*!< Array holding all processes in the system. */
00283 
00284 extern const struct executable_image* const
00285 ELF_images_start;
00286 /*!< The first executable image in the linked list of executable images. */
00287 
00288 extern const char* const
00289 ELF_images_end;
00290 /*!< The address of the first byte after the end of the last ELF image. This
00291      variable is used for sanity checking. */
00292 
00293 /*! \note Linked lists are terminated with a thread with a next index of -1. */
00294 
00295 extern struct thread_queue
00296 ready_queue;
00297 /*!< The ready queue. */
00298 
00299 extern int
00300 timer_queue_head;
00301 /*!< The index, into thread_table, of the head of the timer queue. The timer
00302      queue is a list of threads blocked waiting for the system clock to reach
00303      a certain time.  This variable is set to -1 if there are no threads in
00304      the timer queue. */
00305 
00306 extern long
00307 system_time;
00308 /*!< This variable holds the current system time. The system time is the
00309      number of clock  ticks since system start. There are 200 clock ticks
00310      per second. */
00311 
00312 extern struct CPU_private
00313 cpu_private_data;
00314 /*!< Holds data private to the CPU. */
00315

00318 /*! This fuction initializes the kernel after the assembly code portion has
00319     set the system and the CPU up. */
00320 extern void
00321 initialize(void);
00322 
00323 /*! This function gets called from the syscall handler and responds to the
00324     system calls. */
00325 extern void
00326 system_call_handler(void);
00327 
00328 /*! This function gets called from the interrupt handler and manages timer
00329     interrupts. */
00330 extern void
00331 timer_interrupt_handler(void);

00333 /*! Outputs a string to the bochs console. */
00334 extern void
00335 kprints(const char* const string
00336         /*!< points to a null terminated string */
00337         );
00338

00340 extern void
00341 kprinthex(const register long value
00342           /*!< the value to be written */);
